The whole "must be missing for 24 hours" thing convinced me that if you do know someone who went missing, you should just tell them they went missing the day before. The "dogs sweat by salivating" thing actually comes from the parallel between humans regulating their body temperature by sweating and dogs mainly regulating their body temperature by panting.

The penny thing refers to spinning the penny on a table, it’ll fall on the tail side up. But flipping it in the air would be a different thing and the 80% rule doesn’t apply (:
Black body is an object that does not reflect light. Technically the sun is a black body because it radiates light, but does not reflect light. PewDiePie is actually correct on this, kinda impressed
jesus was most likely born in spring or summer, Australians: thats christmas

The sun is really white, but what you said about the black body is also true. A black body is simply a (somewhat awkward) name for an object that absorbs all light. A black body spectrum relates to how a black body would release its light after it became a certain temperature by absorbing all that light. So to summarize: the sun is white (because it emits all colours of light and those combine in white), but it has a black body spectrum (because physics calls it that). Hope that cleared something up :)
Honestly so glad to hear that Felix agrees that removing dislikes is stupid.
SpongeBob had it right this whole time. Leif Erikson day is really what we should be celebrating.

“Black body” does not mean something is black, but it is a concept used when talking about light emission.  Sort of a “if we assume all the light coming from his thing is emitted from it (not reflected from other sources), what is the spectrum of light?” kind of thing.  Truly black objects absorb all incoming light- that’s why they are black- so that’s why hot things that radiate visible light are treated as such.

The sun’s spectrum is very white.

5:56 My wife once "worked" on a pharmacy when she was very young (just helped organize things because she was a minor) and she was curious about what people say about ammoniac knocking you off. She just opened a tiny pot and smell it a bit and she said that she felt like she "disconnected" from her body for about one or half second and went straight to the floor lol, it didn't last for a long time, it was very fast. Fast forward to the present, she now married to me and graduated and licensed in pharmacochemical-biochemistry (I hope that makes sense because I'm not sure how to translate that career to English), she told me that chloroform is known to cause that dizziness but that ammoniac is the true thing that do knock people off in an instant and the effects can last long depending on the concentration and time consumed.

9:05 Note that having multiple personalities is still a thing, just not in schizophrenia.
multiple personality disorder is no longer in diagnostic classification, since 1980 it's been referred to as Dissociative identity disorder. DID has been officially recognised in the DSM (America) since then and will also be part of the ICD(rest of the world) 11th edition which will be effective starting at the end of this year.

People with DID aren't violent like the media betrays them to be. People with DID are in fact victims of abuse since DID is caused by severe repeated trauma during childhood. People with DID have therefore gone through some of the most horrendous trauma imaginable, although they most likely won't remember it since DID makes the host, the personality/"alter" that is present the majority of the time, forget the trauma as a defence mechanism, often other alters hold the trauma for the host.

It's similar for schizophrenia, they are often the victims of abuse rather then perpetrators, I think my psychology teacher said they are actually less likely to be violent compared to other people but I can't confirm the source on that one.

note: don't take what I say as gospel, I'm just someone with a strong interest in psychology with no qualifications in psychology(I did psychology A level for one year then dropped out to focus on physics and maths), nor do I have or know anyone with DID or Schizophrenia. This is just stuff I've learned from my own research

common misconception about gravity: people knew that everything was pulled by a force for thousands of years. they just had different explanations for it besides Newtonian gravity. in fact, most scientists of the day agreed that Aristotle’s understanding of pull was more credible than Newton’s because Newton was unable to provide a mechanism for gravity other than saying that it was an invisible force that he could not explain. A mechanical explanation would not be given until Einstein

10:00 The interior light does make it more difficult to see outside the car when it's darker outside than inside. Try looking out a window at night with the light on in your house, anything that's not directly under a light source is obscured by the reflection of what's inside.

The bullets breaking locks thing entirely depends on the lock and the gun. Looking a handguns, like a .45 will blast a small lock to pieces.
A 9mm would likely punch directly through a basic lock.
But somthing small like a .22 would do not much at all.
